column11: Review Text

column8: If you like folk museums you will like this place
column11: Interesting exhibits this local museum - the masks are particularly good. Mannequins would benefit from an update though.
Wonderful introduction to folk culture in Sri Lanka. Display explanation in English. Well signed for the way through the museum so you do not miss out. Well worth a visit.
Nice place to learn  Sri Lankan culture Here many types of sri lankan culture were explained through properties . Can learn, feel and understand

When we first saw this was on our route, we assumed was a museum about folk history in the English sense, and then read a little about Martin Wickramasinghe and his body of works, and sounded really interesting and different to all our other stops. The folk part basically means the history of the Sri Lankan people with particular relevance to the countryside traditions and agriculture - and that was even better as a rounded view of the pre-industrial era in Sri Lanka. A great collection of traditional dress, tools, vehicles and more. And then there is the buildings devoted to the life of the author also. We took a guide who was super informative and had a great two-way conversation about so much about Sri Lankan life and the context of the author's life. Very happy we went, beautiful calm place. I think we sent somewhere between an hour and an hour and a half, but could of stayed longer time permitting, but also you could easily cut it down to a 45 mins or less visit if so minded. Great experience, good value.

Very educational place for all the people. It is very helpful for kids who are doing Sri Lankan education. Most of the required historical items are there. This is also a wonderful place to study the life of late Mr.Martin Wickramasinghe who is a popular author. Main place in the museum is the  house where he was born. Facilities and some renovations, improvements can be made to the place ,so it can attract more visitors. It's a place you should visit when you're in Galle.

Located in Koggala, Sri Lanka, is a large museum complex that dipicts the culture and life of rural Sri Lanka.  The artifacts exhibited related o the arts and crafts, folk art and folk life of locals.  Clothing, jewelry, folk games, medical devices, transport (wagons, canoes and carts) religious artifacts and education tools are displayed in the many different buildings.  The house where Martin Wickramasinghe was born is an important part of the complex and is a home typical of the headman, teacher, and the native physician during the 19th century. A library containing the works of the writer is located at the entrance.  Plan on 1-2 hours if you slowly browse--1 hours if you hurry through.  Not much of interest for children in my opinion.

column8: Place to experience Sri Lankan culture / traditions in low country
column11: Place was the home of greatest author of Sri Lanka Martin Wickramasinghe. Further there is a museum relating to his life and traditional culture of Sri Lanka. Specialy foreigners must visit this place if you want to enjoy the culture of Sri Lankans.
We stopped here for an hour on our way to Galle, and it was OK, but lacked specific details regarding most of the items, like the dates.
If you want to get a glimpse into Sri Lankan literature and charm of life in Sri Lanka, this is a place to visit.

column8: Very interesting Museum, with Southern province history and culture
column11: Excellent location to learn about Martin Wickremesinghe, the culture of Koggala and history of the Southern province. Houses all his family heirlooms and information is very clear and educational.

A must visit if you go to Koggala! The museum is the only building remaining of the ancient Koggala town which was razed to the ground in 1942 to make way for a Royal Air Force base during World War II. The house is the birth place of Martin Wickramasinghe and is filled with ancient historic times that was collected by his family , including masks, clothing, vehicles, boats and a number of historical utensils, accessories and instruments.

This museum is situated on the Galle-Matara main road in Koggala. There are two parts here: Folk museum and house of Martin Wickramasinghe. It is the ancestral home of the renowned Sri Lankan writer and poet Martin Wickramasinghe (1890-1976) where he lived with his family. The surviving part of the house has been converted into a museum complex displaying artifacts, photographs, awards and souvenirs of great writer. This house was the only remains of old Koggala village as all other was razed to the ground in 1942 to make way for an air force base. Visitors can view his life story by photos displayed at museum. The folk museum exhibits the life of southern Sri Lankans: Life of fishermen, traditional cuisine, Kolam masks, colonial crockery, ancient jewellery etc. No photographs allowed inside the museum but can get at Wickramasinghe house. Tombs of Mr. and Mrs. Wickramasinghe are also situated here. There is a book stall of Martin Wickramasinghe at the entrance.
Interesting place for a visit. The museum tells a lot about Sri Lankan Heritage. The house of the famous author is pretty Interesting.Really enjoyed the visit
We thought it was a small place but it was huge! Lots of different sections in many different buildings. Thought we’d be an hour - 3 hours later we had nearly finished! Really interesting.
Great explanation of the life and work of Mr. Martin Wickramasinghe...... The house is preserved nicely to show the ancient Sri Lankan culture....

Suddenly had to join with my daughters school excursion .imagine would be a boring cause of kids but they are very funny deeply enjoyed.kids are our world we must respect them. I thought we are teachers.but we are learning from kids even they are very advance.must visit place recommend no hesitation he is my one of favorite writer great person.salute sir

We have stayed close to here many times but never visited so our friend to us. It worth a visit to see the old traditions and how people lived. Plus of course the birth place and house of Martin Wickramasinghe. Really enjoyed it.

We visited twice a few weeks apart.  On the second occasion our guide was totally disinterested and explained very little, totally unlike that of our first visit. This place is a combination of the first homeplace of Wickramasinghe and has exhibits relating to his life and work.  It is also an interesting folk museum with exhibits relating to local life, work, crafts and culture over the centuries.
Some interesting artefacts and the staff are helpful with explanations. The garden is pretty. Unfortunately it all feels a bit run down. No photos of exhibits allowed.

Martin Wickramainghe is a very important writer and person in the development of the modern Sri Lanka. Most of the museum is display of Sri Lankan folklore, but the house he was born in is very interesting. Most of his books, translated into English can be purchased at the museum.

We visited this place with a group. It’s a lovely place, great historical artefacts and fantastic flora. It was a nice stay however I missed a little bit the background information. Our guide was (in my view) average and I wounder if another guide could have made more out of it.

We participated in a hotel excursion combined with a river road trip to local people harvesting and selling cinnamon. The museum has a nice collection but the items are rather dusty. So I did not take pics. Bring your own water bottle. The garden is also nice but some trees are affected by mushrooms.

2000 or so LKR got us a return tuk tuk trip from Unawatuna to the museum and lake on a rainy morning. We spent an hour and half guided around the place by a knowledgeable elderly gentleman who really brought the exhibits to life. Set in a garden with many specimen trees, most of the place is undercover so perfect for us that day. I would thoroughly recommend it- I know so much more now about the country and the remarkable man who created it. Beats sitting in a bar all day!

We were unprepared for how large this complex is--it's really practically a whole village with multiple displays in multiple buildings.  A very nice guide attached himself to us but unfortunately he really wanted to show us everything and we were tired and eager to move on to our next stop.  I really appreciated all the labels on things, even the trees.

I had never heard of this prolific author when our driver suggested this place. We very much enjoyed the museum's artifacts, as well as learning about Wickramasinghe's story and seeing his birthplace.Well worth an hour or so of your time.

An interesting place with many artifacts from colonial and pre-colonial Ceylon. It commemorates the life and times of one of Sri Lanka's best and prolific authors and contains many souvenirs and photos of his life. He wanted the culture to be remembered and collected much of the contents. Presentation is quite good and the exhibits well displayed; although the whole place is a little tired. We were assisted by a guide who helped a little. We did not ask for him but he sort of latched on to us as we arrived. No commercial arrangement was discussed until the end, and inevitably he was not totally happy with my tip. I had to explain the essence of contract law.
Museum of the greatest Sri Lankan writer , Mr Martin Wickramasingha. Many old items exibited in the museum alon side the old , well preserved home of Mr.Wickramasingha . Many things to see for kids.
Wonderful insight to one of Sri Lanka's greatest writers. Not only a history of the writer but an interesting in site to Sri Lankan history.

If you want to feal and experience the unfake, real essence of Sri Lankan village wealth in calm and relaxing environment, this is one of the best place in down south. It also holds invaluable information about the greaterst book author Martin Wickramsinghe and his way of life blend with nature. Once you will be there you will feel soothing effect of natural environment and you can see Sri Lankan architectural design which incooporate with nature doing minimum harm to it.
An interesting collection of both Sri Lankan life and the life of Martin Wickramasinghe, worth an hour or so of your time, a minute's walk from the main road, lovely gardens.

We spent a little over an hour at this museum, and it was a good way to learn about the history and culture of Sri Lanka. I found it especially interesting how this one house has survived only because a British officer's wife had decided to use it as her personal quarters. The amount of effort that has gone into putting the museum together and keeping it running is commendable, but the place could do with a little bit of a clean up now. Overall, a good thing to do if you're keen on understanding a little more about the folk history of the area.
This is athe home of a sri lankan artist which has been preserved as museum. A great place to visit to see lankan culture and history.
A old house and surroundings converted into museum and maintained beautifully. You will get sense of true Lankan culture here

A really interesting collection of artefacts which really help to illustrate Sri Lankan culture and folk history. Some items could do with a bit of a clean and polish, but nevertheless this museum is well worth a stop-off on your way along the south coast, or as a half-day excursion from Galle.
this is the birth place or the lived house of great Sri lankan Author Martin Wickramasinghe, everything he used has kept accodingly, village place of koggala

A very historic place of an exceptional man who lead the Sri Lankan literature to the international level. A very educational place for people of all ages. The extended museum carries many different varieties of history. Do pay a visit when you visit Galle or when you pass by further towards the Southern side of Sri Lanka.

Great little museum with some cool rustic artifacts and a good deal on the author himself. Just up the road is the airfield/strip where the Catalinas used to fly out of in WW2. Theres a DC3 aircraft which you can explore in the resturant just up the road.

The museum complex is an excellent place to know more about folk culture and history of Sri Lanka. Surely a place to spend 2-3 hours soaking in all the information you can get from artifacts there. We were lucky to meet with a very helpful employee of the museum who gave us detailed knowledge about various part of the museum and gave us enough time on each of the exhibitions.
Very easy to understand how was earlier sri lankan life style and condition.Can see at there very nice old vehicle and how they were make their own life in ago 200 years.

This is the place where one of prominent Sri Lankan novelist & creative writer Martin Wickramasinghe spent his life. Folk museum located in Koggala around 15-20kms from Galle towards to Matara. Every Sri Lankan school children must visit place.
In the field trip we managed to witness the collection of historical monuments of the previous centuries. It really helped to broaden our horizons.

The Author is one of my favorites and I've read many of his books. The place takes you back to these books as it explain the nature of the place and the surrounding as written in books. It takes you a different world where you feel that you live in the books that you've read.

Lanka. The museum has almost every icon related to the Sri Lankan history. This is nice place situated at Galle and you need to travel around 12 km from highway exit from Galle to reach this place.  This museum is a beautiful place to visit if you want to get an idea of life in Sri Lanka in a previous era. The place is really beautiful. Highly recommend. It is a beautifully curated museum depicting the livelihoods, costumes and traditions of Sri Lanka. The artifacts are tastefully arranged, well maintained and descriptions of the exhibits are very clear and concise. The items are methodically arranged in different buildings around the very large property. This museum complex houses a number of historical artifacts, implements and photographs which are very rare to find nowadays even in Sri Lankan homes. A must see for the Sri Lankan kids to appreciate what life was like in olden days.   Mr. Wickramasinghe was one of the most honoured writers of Sri Lanka, by both western and eastern world. His writing style depicted the simplicity inherited by our ancestors. This is his birth place. There are a lot of photographs and almost all his books and there is a bookshop to buy his books.  On a higher ground, his and his beloved wife's tombs can be seen. The sense of comfort and peacefulness that you will get when you enter this place is profound. The grounds are shady and is well kept with named specimen trees and lily ponds. The exhibition buildings, thought a little hot and stuffy are full of fascinating exhibits and photographs and the guides are helpful and well informed.  The highlight of the museum compound is the residence of the writer himself. The extensive selection of his personal items gives a very thorough indication of his life, works and his contribution to the literary society. The gardens of the huge compound are beautifully maintained with huge selection of indigenous trees that are all well labeled.  There is a bookshop with a limited selection of English translations of Mr. Wickramasinghe's books.   When you visit his house you will understand that simplicity will help you to find that balance. Also there is a place to eat if you bring foods from outside. This museum is definitely worth a visit if you are in the Galle area.
Excellent cultural experience. Well worth the visit to learn more of such a scholar and books he authored.

We visited  this place with my 77 year old father and our five year old son and there was something there for each one of us. Entering this complex transported us into a different world - a world of history, rural charm, folklore. From Martin Wickremasinghe’s ancestral home, to the various boats and carts, to his burial place, there is so much to see here; details that offer rich insights on both the author’s life and on Sri Lankan history. Walking around these premises is an extremely relaxing experience- and we left determined to learn more about both Martin Wickremasinghe and that particular period in Sri Lankan history.

Excellent place to study ancient Sri Lankan culture..They got Very rare collection covering most of the areas but need to provide more detail else visitors need to come with background knowledge to grab maximum from there . I suggest them to provide comprehensive leaflet before enter the museum.really worth to visit specially for students who study the history and culture of Sri Lanka. Photography is prohibited inside the museum.

“Martin Wickramasinghe" delved into the life and culture of our people from their early beginning to the present day and through his writings, he identified our folk culture as a resilient bonding substance which has not only prevented our social disintegration and alienation, despite assimilation of elements from a multitude of eastern and western cultures, but also moulded our collective identity and values as a people. Wickramasinghe’s unceasing intellectual exploration and his creative and critical writings relating to the life and culture of the people of Sri Lanka continued for a period of over 70 years”. The Folk museum is an ideal place to get to know the author better, to understand a little of what Koggala and its people meant to him. Wickramasinghe’s writings vividly recall the carefree days of his childhood, exploring the marine life in the Koggala reef, playing with his friends from the village and enjoying the rural solitude of his beloved Koggala. Seated on the steps of Wickramasinghe’s ancestral home, and enjoying the blessed charm of this seven acre piece of rural paradise, it is easy to understand why this piece of earth nurtured and set ablaze the imagination of one of this country’s greatest writers.

The museum is based on the life of one of Sri Lanka’s most famous writers; their so called “Shakespeare”. The museum consists of his original house and many items and photos from his life. However most interesting part for us was the collection of historical items from the Portugese, Dutch and English periods. One of the guides told us, very proudly, about the history of his country. It was definitely worth visiting If you are in this area (visiting time approx. 2-3 hours).

We found this gem by accident. It was a wonderful walk through some history. We were so into it, we ended up buying some books which we read as kids and re read them. Of course they were written my Martin Wickramasinghe.

We really had a good time at this museum.  We had a guide take us all the way through, showing us the collection of the Sri Lankan writer, Milton Wickramasinghe, who wrote over 100 books about life in Sri Lanka.  He was an avid collector of all things Sri Lankan and this museum houses that collection.  Jewelry, kitchen implements, vehicles, everything under the sun.  If you have time and have an interest in the culture of Sri Lanka, please go here.

This museum is well worth a visit if you're staying in or around Koggala. Not expensive at time of our visit 200 rupees approx £1.00. It is housed in a number of buildings and features various objects showing the life and styles of the local people including various carts, boats, dress etc. Interestingly this area was covered by many dwellings which during the 2nd world war was evacuated within 24 hours to built an airfield and only the Martin Wickramasinghe house remains..

Martin Wickramasinghe was an author and leading intellectual in early 20th century Sri Lanka.  He and his wife created a trust museum to protect his collections, and the house in which he was born.  Religious objects, as well as farming implements, musical instruments, masks & puppets, medical tools, canoes and fishing traps and vehicles pulled by animals are among the artifacts displayed in cases.  Some rooms and furnishings and a coconut oil mill are also on the grounds.  We visited the Wickramasinghe Museum of Folk Culture on a day tour that also included the Handunugoda Tea Factory.  We traveled by tuk tuk from Galle Fort.

We found this a fascinating place and knowing nothing about this man was surprised at his life. It is not a normal experience for overseas visitors we surmise but the old buildings and gardens are a haven from all the other busy things that are now are going on all around. Great for seeing the old ways of life in Sri Lanka and lots of interesting birds all around in the garden. Very good value and so pleased we made the effort.

This museum was a pleasant surprise. I was staying in a hotel in Koggala in 3 minute walking distance from the museum but postponed the visit until the end of my vacation as I didn't think the museum was really worthy. It was a mistake. I really liked the collection of traditional Sri Lankan masks, the wooden statue of the demon king Ravana and lots of other exhibits. The territory of the museum compex is also quite extensive and very pleasant to walk. Photography inside the buildings is prohibited, but you can take pictures outside in the park. The entrance fee is 200 LKR (about 1,3 USD).

This is the best Folk museum Sri lanka, Martin wickramasinghe '' The Farther of the modern sinhala literature '', here you can see his home and overview of his life and also the place is a huge collection of antiques, old monuments dated back to late 1800's. 200rs for foreigners and 50rs for the locals. must visit place. you can visit renovated home where the sri lankan great Author was born, also the museum contains folk artifacts belong to sri lankan histoey. costumes, instruments, masks and many, also some items belong different industries ex - fishing industry and clothing industry. taking photographs not allowed inside the museum. very informative place - not to miss !!
if you're around Koggala, you should not miss this place. entrance is Rs50 for locals and Rs200 for foreigners, legendary Martin Wickramsinghe's house and museum.
This is a must visit place, specially for kids. Museum has wide collections of antiques dated back to late 1800's.
One of the best Folk museums in Galle. Very educational to kids of all age groups. Can get crowded but well worth a visit if you are in Koggala area.

This museum has a partially renovated home where the Sri Lankan author was born in 1890, as well as his burial site.  Today, the museum contains various folk artifacts from throughout Sri Lanka's history, including costumes, musical instruments, giant puppets (my favorite), masks and kitchen utensils.
This folk museum contains variety of information about our rich culture.  I'm so grateful to Martin Wickramasinghe Trust.

This museum is dedicated to Sri Lanka folk arts. Well thought out and offers qa lot of long lost games, traditions etc. Superb collection of 19 century masks. lovely garden... well worth the visit if you are in koggala area.

We visited  museum  on April  2016. It's  nice and  small  museum  in folk style.  As for a foreigner  it was  interesting to  see  old money, dishes, clothes, religious things, old village  houses, transportation. I  recommend to visit.

We happened across the museum today as it is opposite our hotel. Really glad we did as it was a great way to spend a couple of hours learning more about Sri Lanka's history. The trees outside are labelled and interesting too. The entrance fee is small and worth it. We inadvertently ended up with a tour guide showing us around (for a tip) which was actually very good. He had very good English and helped us to understand more than the basic. It's a popular spot for local school groups which made for a lovely environment.

It costs next to nothing to go in, the grounds of MW's house are extensive, cool and tranquil, the folk museum is beautifully presented and fascinating, and was improved by the guide who adopted us and explained the exhibits. The house with all MW's mementos is also interesting as the displays are so personal. So for a bite sized insight into Sri Lankan history, culture and life this museum can hardly be faulted. It's all on the flat, so no problems there, we were there for about an hour and a half, and came away with change from 1000 rupees, having paid the entrance fee, a tip for the guide and bought a book. Take a bottle of water, no refreshments there, and no photos inside the exhibitions. So, it's cheap, pleasant and informative, go there!
Martine wikramasinghe museum is the best place to learn about Mr.Martin Wikramasinghe and his background. This near by Kokgala...

We were not expecting too much from this visit but what pleasant surprise‼️ We had our own guide who was very knowledgable and a good communicator. The story of this Author's life and the insight into the Sri Lankan way of life was simply outstanding. A must do visit fir anyone who wants to learn more about Sri Lanka
If you are interested In srilankan history and culture you should visit this place. Very peaceful and lovely environment.Definitely worth the effort going to see it.

Martin W is effectively the father of modern sinhaleae literature, having penned over 100 books in his lifetime. Here, you can see his home and a small overview of his life. Quite enjoyable, but I think you would need one of the grounds staff to help explain the significance of what's on display. The same goes for the cultural museum that offers lots of interesting and diverse aspects of Sinhaleae culture from medical implements to drums to religious artefacts and looms, all displayed fairly well. Spend an hour here for a quick dip into Sri Lanka culture.

I thought this place would be really boring but i guess i was wrong. It was a very interesting one. Better than the colombo museum. There is alot to learn specially it will benefit all the students who are learning history as a subject.

A must visit place, well presented with a historic memorabilia of the well known writer.  It was good to see not only the belongings of the great legend  but also the culture and historic utensils and clothing.  It was good to see the house that Mr Martin Wickramasinghe lived in the same format.  The gardens are well maintained.

This place takes you back in time, with the memories of Martin Wickramasinghe belongings and other displays at the museum. If you want to learn about Sri Lanka and its culture make sure to visit. The only thing I found bad was the toilet which was not clean and not maintained. The place offers greenery and peace with rich culture.
This place is filled with old sri lankan culture related village related things. beautiful to see. Some are not related to Martin Wickramasinghe but all the things tells beautiful folk tales.

The  place of a great writer, and now a museum. The museum displays a wonderful collection of artefacts and memorabilia. Which includes traditional dress through the ages, farm and fishing implements. You walk through the grounds from building to building in a tranquil setting. Very user friendly as the grounds are on a flat serface. Well worth a visit if in the area.
antiques and Memories of Martin Wicramashinha's will be displayed, one of the greatest writer who lived in Sri Lanka will be honored at this place.
This is a great place that showing history of Sri lanka and story of great writer Martin Wickramasinghe.

Our driver asked if we would like to stop in and glad we did this was really interesting and great museum.we also ended up buying a couple of books which is not something we would usually do, worth spending an hour having a look through.
If you are interested In srilankan history and culture you should visit this place. Calm place covered by various trees.
this is the place of sri lankan gratest writer Martin wicramasinghe's birth place. now this place become a museum .we can see many things related to martin wickramasinghe and sri lankan history
Very peaceful and lovely environment Lots of things to see You can earn a good knowledge about our ancient rural life Must visit this place

Martin Wickramasinghe was a Sri Lankan novelist.He was born in 1890  in the town of Koggala in Southern Sri Lanka.The house in which Martin Wickramasinghe was born has inspired the Martin Wickramasinghe Trust to established a Folk Museum Complex.It is situated in Koggala in Southern province.The Folk museum is an ideal place to get to know the author better, to understand a little of what Koggala and its people meant to him.

This museum is skiped by many tourists, but it is well worth a visit. You can combine it with a visit to the turtle farm and hatchery (3km apart). You can go by bus or tuk tuk. The entrance fee is only 200rs and the museum is well maintained. There are even free guides a your service. There are 4 buildings with a variety of objects and everything is also written in english. The trees in the garden have have their names written on little signs.

Really enjoyed the variety this museum has to offer. Very easy to get to just jump on a local bus. 200 rupees entrance fee. This would be a great museum for all ages, lots to keep kids interested too. A guide showed us around for ages which was included in the price. 12km out of Galle but deffo worth going to see.
Provides a good knowledge about the life of Sri Lankans, may be a generation ago. Well maintained estate and feel like an oasis with such greenery.

Interesting exhibit, nice place. He was an important man. The collection of artifacts is extensive.Beware of hords of well behaved schoolkids days before Holidays though. They tend to pay more attention to you than to the exhibits. But nice and friendly as usual.

We rented a tuk one day to take us from Galle  to Mirissa so we could stop as we chose along the way, the was one of the places we stopped. The museum is actually quite  large, a fair amount of history, one of   the few remaining houses since the British occupation,  the  grounds are serene and peaceful, a pleasant surprise.
This place is often overlooked by tourists. It is a real eye opener into the life of rural Sri Lanka. It has social history covered over the centuries.

I have been here twice, very serene environment. Wikramasinghe's home, a tiny house where he was born and lived, he is a famous Sri lankan writer and traveled a lot and is a great Sri lankan author. The museum next to the house displays a lot of culture, history and economical activities of the Sri Lankan people. No place to sit and chill, it would have been great to have a decent tea shop/coffee cafe within this area.

This is a place to be visited by book lovers and the old house of Martin Wickremasinghe was a great sight to visit. The museum gives an insight to the history of Sri Lanka and you can also buy books at this place..

I came here with some of my friends on a Friday afternoon with lunch, and this place really shows the intelligence of Sri Lankans from the early pages of history, there was also the evolution of Sinhala letters. After checking the local history, we came to the house of Martin Wickramasinghe where he was born, and died (his grave his outside his house with his family's graves) It was really wonderful and I bought three awesome books, one of Martin's famous books was, Madol Doova.
Beautiful environment and calm down.very peaceful.the museum show our traditional power.sri Lankans must be proud about this place

The house in which Martin Wickramasinghe was born has inspired the Martin Wickramasinghe Trust to established a Folk Museum Complex, surrounded by a restored ecosystem planted with hundreds of varieties of indigenous trees and shrubs in which bird life abounds. The house and the surroundings brings to life a little part of the Koggala which is so vividly depicted in Wickramasinghe’s writings.

The museum and the authors old house is a must see place in Koggala (Galle). It is not a place you feel you can visit again. **SPOILER ALERT*** The Museum has nothing to do with author or his life. The things in that museum reflects the ancient Sri Lankan culture and some of the items relates to the events in authors books.
The famouse sri lankan author's museum. If around good to pay a visit. Its a small museum doesnt need hours to look around

Fabulous way to spend a couple of hours on our tour of sti lanka we had a very knowledgeable guide who told us about each exhibit.When you look at some of the artifacts you realise things haven"t changed that much over the centuries in sti lanka.Visit if you have the time.

You mustn't miss this wonderful museum if you travel from Colombo to Matara. Can cover up in 2-3 hours and the museum has almost every icon related to the Sri Lankan history.  There's a nice excursion with Lotus Holidays and Events we tried.

This is nice place situated at Galle. you need to travel around 12 km from highway exit at galle to reach this place. you can come early morning or evening is better. if you come to this place dont foget to buy a  book called  " upanday sita" which is the best book worte by Marin wickramasinghe. Also there is a place to eat if you bring foods from outside .

This museum complex houses a number of historical artifacts, implements and photographs which are very rare to find nowadays even in Sri Lankan homes. A must see for the kids to appreciate what life was like in olden days.

If you happen to know the greatest writer of Sri Lanka, or if you have no idea about him, this is the place you must visit. Mr. Wickramasinghe was one of the most honoured writers of Sri Lanka,  by both western and eastern world. His writing style depicted the simplicity inherited by our ancestors. This is his birth place. There are a lot of photographs and almost all his books and there is a bookshop to buy his work. On a higher ground, his and his beloved wife's tombs can be seen.

You might ask the question why would a world famous writer  live in a outstation area rather in living in Colombo.You will find your answer when you visit here.That sense of comfort and peacefulness that you will get when you enter this place is profound.we all try to find that balance in our life.when you visit his house you will understand that simplicity will help you to find that balance.If you are in Galle this is one place you must visit. I promise it will have a effect on you.

This museum is definitely worth a visit if you are in the Galle area. The grounds are shady and well kept with named specimen trees and lily ponds. The exhibition buildings whilst a little hot and stuffy are full of fascinating exhibits and photographs and the guides are helpful and well informed. There is a bookshop with a limited selection of English translations of Mr. Wickramasinghe's books. After visiting the museum we crossed the road to The Fortress Hotel for a light lunch and a touch of luxe.

This museum is a beautiful place to visit if you want to get an idea of life in Sri Lanka in a previous era. Martin Wickramasinghe has left us an amazing collection and educational resource - SrI Lanka is rightfully proud of their most famous author. The place is really beautiful. Highly recommend.

It is a beautifully curated museum depicting the livelihoods, costumes and traditions of Sri Lanka. The artifacts are tastefully arranged, well maintained and descriptions of the exhibits are very clear and concise. The items are methodically arranged in different buildings around the very large property. The highlight of the museum compound is the residence of the writer himself. The extensive selection of his personal items gives a very thorough indication of his life, works and his contribution to the literary society. The gardens of the huge compound are beautifully maintained with huge selection of indigenous trees that are all well labeled. The tour ends with a tiny yet well-stocked bookshop selling all his works in both English and Sinhala – all of which are very reasonably priced. All this for just Rs.40  - what more can you ask for!

The museum is an intriguing place. It is quite run down but contains a vast array of historic gems, including the guides, some of whom will delight in explaining in detail every single item on display!

if you are interested in craft and craft heritage this is a must see in Sri Lanka. a fantastic selection of household and everyday handmade objects as well as some slightly more industrial and ceremonial. Some wonderful massive catamaran hulls. Slightly frustrating that the information on objects remains a little vague but highly recommended none the less. I believe that the museum is currently entirely privately funded so you support is really valuable.
if you really wanna see sri lankans village life and the past go to this place this is the only place you can see that really well '''
If you are interested in The Folk Lore of Sri Lanka then this is a must visit Museum.Martin Wickramasinghe left a legacy of knowledge for the people of Sri Lanka to enjoy forever.

Incredible collection of Sri Lankan folk art. The collection of 19 century masks, especially those of various communities, British officials etc. are very rare and fascinating. So is the collection of the carts and various forms of transport. Set in a huge garden, the museum is a treasure trove of folk art . It is also interesting to see how they have preserved everything of Sri Lanka's foremost author including his old house.
Martin Wicramasinghe is a very important writer in SriLanka. In here we can see many belongings that he have used. After visiting this museum it is recommend to go Madol doowa.

Unless you are familiar with his work, it will only give you an insight into the tools/culture during his era. Even a slight bit of familiarity with his subject will provide greater context to the exhibits

it's a delightful and interesting place that just goes on and on. You should have a guide with you to explain what you see or you will probably miss out. Lots of trees that are well marked shade the walk ways (it's HOT). the museum does a good job of depicting the medieval and ancient cultures, etc. Loved the masks and displays of old boats, carriages, etc. in particular. Don't miss the birth place and living place of Martin Wickramasinghe - a little house. You have to take off your shoes but if you don't want to do that you can walk around the house and peer inside the windows to get a little glimpse.
sadly you do get an individual tour guide which may be more thorough than you'd like, but there is an awful lot of interesting stuff here. The guide did not want a tip! refreshing.

This is the best place I have seen so far in Sri Lanka which depicts the ancient and medieval cultures and sub-cultures that prevailed in Sri Lanka. Having traveled all over this small island I had the misconception that I knew Sri Lankan History very well. But the cultural, agricultural, architectural, fisheries etc knowledge I summoned by visiting this place was tremendous. Apart from the Old Martin Wickremesinghe residence which I visited as a kid many years back, the addition of the new folk museum is a good opportunity for tourists as well as Sri Lankans with such interests to learn a lot within a couple of  hours. A small book outlet is situated near the entrance which has Martin Wickremesinghe's collection with English translations as well
Nice museum complex to to visit in Galle. It's the birth place and living place of Martin Wickramasinghe. Check for info in : http://www.martinwickramasinghe.info/english/museum/
It was okay. Maybe because it was not really in line with our interests. The area itself was clean, easily accessible with sufficient parking.

This is a great little museum highlighting the house of the literary genius Martin Wickramasinghe. The museum covers the culture and life in the area and is a great resource for a children and adults alike. Highly recommended.

Come hear if you want to see Sri Lankan history 100 years ago. 200R is worth it. Well curated and surprisingly large collection of artefacts. Enjoy the garden too but bring water and sunhat as it's hot! Bought Martin Wickramasinghe's Madol Doova book for 160R. Enjoyable!

That is a great place to visit if you want to get an idea of life in Sri Lanka 100 years ago. One of the best writers, SrI lanka was ever gifted. The place is really beautiful. Please do not visit this palce if you do not want to see southern Sri Lankan village 100 years ago.

We enjoyed the simplicity and sincerity of this lovely Museum. It is such a fascinating place to visit. The museum comprises an extensive and rich collection of Sri Lankan artefacts, beautifully curated and housed in an interesting variety of buildings all scattered through a charming garden. Highly recommended.

This is where the greatest writer Mr. Martin wickramasinghe was born. Not it is a museum. There are a lot of items that he used and his hand writings, every book he wrote, awards and medals he got, etc. Whole garden is properly maintained and environment is mind relaxing. But when the time I visit there, sunny and burning hot. Trees could make soft condition but still hot. 10 minute walking from the Koggala station along the railway line. Its better walking if you came here by train.

We took the local bus from Galle bus station to Koggalla since it was a bit far for tuk tuk. The trip took about 25 min. It was a short 15 min walk after we got off the bus. Straight ahead till we saw the Fortress Hotel then make a left, cross the little train track and there it is.  Really enjoyed learning about the culture and life of rural Sri Lanka. Some really cool artifacts. I think the entrance fee was 200 rs. Well worth the visit. We stopped by the Fortress hotel for some cold beverages and amazing ocean views before heading back to Galle.

We visited this museum as it was opposite our hotel so we were able to walk there. A guide "attached" himself to us once we had paid the entry fee and initially we felt a bit hijacked but actually we were glad he showed us round as we would have missed an awful lot of information about all the trees as well as the other exhibits and information about Martin Wickramasinghe himself. It is a small museum but we spent a very happy and interesting 90 minutes there and would recommend it for a visit.
Very large collection of historic Sri Lankan clothing, weapons, transport vehicles and boats... too much to mention and a big surprise as we only intended spending an hour there.

Martin Wickramasinghe was one of the greatest authors and intellectuals of Sri Lanka and how good it is that the Wicjramasinghe Trust decided to set up this museum in the house and its surroundings in which he was born. The folk museum had been a wish of Wickramasinghe himself who desired to preserve the artefacts and rural culture of his childhood. Visitors can enjoy many personal items including some of the authors writings, furniture and possessions but much more besides - the museum contains many exhibits depicting the development of agriculture, fishing, pottery, crafts and Sri Lankan culture and rural technology in general. Items are very well displayed with many details written in English. The museum is in peaceful garden surroundings so one can enjoy both indoors and outdoors and happily spend a couple of hours here learning much about the history of the locality and Sri Lankan folk history in general.

This was such a fascinating visit which was enhanced by the obvious pride and pleasure of our guide who showed us round. The entrance fee is minimal and the escorted tour was free. Unfortunately it was very very hot and we ran out of time which prevented us from seeing everything. What we saw was a rich collection of artefacts and heritage, assembled really well in buildings scattered throughout  a beautiful tropical garden. If you'd like to know more about Sri Lankan history and its colonial rulers, this museum is a must see. There were even tribes people who were cannibals! I will definitely return to complete the tour on my next trip. Highly recommended.

This is a beautifully curated museum, full of interesting artefacts and information in English as well as Sinhala. I was drawn to it because of Martin Wickramsinghe's role in authoring many books in Sinhala and enjoyed reading his most popular children's book, Madol Doova (translated into English!)

We loved this place and would have stayed longer than 1 hour if we hadn't come so late as they close at 5pm. The artefacts are displayed really well with lots of descriptions in a English. An older gentleman led us round and explained things to us at no extra charge to the entrance fee, he is obviously proud of his heritage and of the museum. He was very informative. Lots of fishing and farming implements, lace making, gem cutting tools, jewellery, some clothes and a fabulous room full of masks and puppets which was really impressive. You can also wander around the famous Sri Lankan writer's home and see the old bedrooms and his writing desk and many photographs of Wickramasinghe, his family and visiting dignitaries, a selection of old books on display. A genuinely charming place with loads of character and a lot of atmosphere in his old house. We really enjoyed it; not a stuffy museum experience at all. The gardens are beautiful and shy grey langur monkeys were watching us from high in the palm trees. Definitely visit this place, it's like being taken back in time to old Sri Lanka....loved it.

This is the house of veteran Martin Wickramasinghe turned into a museum. Really appreciate the cultural and other stuff there. You are totally into the colonial era when you are in the museum complex. The then real nature of this island especially on southern province is visible with the artifacts displayed there.. truly amazed to see and a must visit especially by a Sri lankan. The 2-3 hours spent is really worth enough and you get a good amount of knowledge on the then Sri lankan life and its evolution over the years.
Antique face masks, tools & many other artifacts. Lovely to spend 2 to 3 hours at the Museum & appreciate the culture & richness of a bygone era. Enjoyed!

Martin Wickramasinghe Folk Museum Complex is one of those places where you can taste the real flavour of this island. the place is not just about him and his work but a hub of information about old Sri Lankan life style. Do Not miss this place if you are in Galle.
A must for both us Sri Lankans and our visiting tourist! For example why are the Southern Sri Lankans so different from those in Colombo or Kandy. The answer lies in this Museum.
Very good display of colonial time life style of Sri Lankan ( Ceylon) Middle class. A must visit during your tour in Galle. The house of an eminent author turned into a museum. A fitting tribute.

Loved the ancient beauty and glamor. So much to learn and so much to teach your kids about the history and things like way of living, transport, food our ancestors had. Also the little island called "Madol Doowa" which is not far away from Koggala.

Visited the museum with 40 girls from the Anula Girls Orphanage and everyone thoroughly enjoyed the morning out. Museum has loads of interesting items and gives an excellent history of Sri Lankan life and its development over the years. Was particularly impressed with the boats and the monsoon wind furnace!. Nice seating area if you fancy a rest in the shade, and Martin W. original house was a great representation of what life must have been like many years ago. All in all, a real hidden gem I would say as not that widely publicised as worth a visit. Not as grand as the Galle Museum, but definitely worth a look for anyone looking for something to do for a morning or afternoon.
Having read his book, Madolduva as a child, it was just really nice to go here and see the author's life on display.. Its a nice place
This is the museum for the greatest Sri Lankan writer of all time. If you are interested in literature, the number one place to visit in whole Sri Lanka.

Martin Wickramasinghe museum is a museum and it has a many of things depicting traditions, tools, culture of the different areas of Sri Lanka which is not seen at the Museum at Colombo. It is an insight to the folk life of the Sri Lanka people of yesteryear. I was amazed to see that Mr. Martin Wickramasinhe has received many Awards & Honors from other countries including the OBE “Order of the British Empire but no honor even posthumously from the Sri Lankan government although it bestows honors on persons who cannot even hold a candle to Mr. Wickramasinghe. There were boards stating “no photography”, “Do not touch the exhibits” but Sri Lankan visitors flouted these rules in broad daylight. There were very old men to guard these who were powerless when brawny men brazenly did not care & took photographs of the exhibits & sat on the antique chairs of Mr. Wickramasinghe. The garden is well laid out & full of rare trees which have name boards. There is no CCTV to cover to monitor this place & it needs professional security staff. It is a shame that such a museum charges on Rs 30 from Sri Lankans & this allows all the ruffians to enter, consume alcohol in the premises & destroy this gem of a museum. I have paid more than US$ 25 to see museums which have less to offer. I feel that Sri Lankans should be charged at least Rs. 500/= per head to visit this museum. The book shop offers Mr. Wickramasinhe’s books at a discounted price. I also found the ruins of Mr. Wickramasinhe’s uncles house adjacent to his house. A Sri Lankan child has to be brought here as many of Mr Wickramasinhes books are used by them as text books. A visit to this museum will give a child in-depth knowledge as to what he used for his stories.

Martin Wickremesinghe is related to my mother and who has lived in this house for a short period in the '50s. We've studied and read his books for years in school and afterwards and am grateful they are now translated very well into English were others can appreciate his genius. The folk museum is a treasure cove with first edition books, his personal wealth and even the English Passport he used to hold :) Any person who has read his books would appreciate the fact how easy it must have been to write and write on in these surroundings and the stories which are rich with his own personal wisdom. The family has donated a lot and have helped find many artifacts of the time and are on display in a fine fashion. Wish there were more plaques with written word to describe the time there were specifically from as not all children who study in Sri Lanka learn it's history.

Being in Ahangama and after having our day at the beach 'rained off' we thought of trying the folk museum. It was a great decision. A very well curated museum in Sri Lankan standards. A great journey through Sri Lanka's history with emphasis on people, costumes and livelihood. Overall very impressive and well looked after. Wondered why photographs without flash were disallowed though!! Anyways for locals the entrance fee was only 30 bucks! Go visit
interesting museum wqith large collection of old dancing masks and carts and forms of transport from the 19 century. I loved the elephant drawn cart which is like the trucks of a hundred years ago!

Our group toured the museum and it was an insight to the folk life of the Sri Lanka people as written by Martin Wickramasinghe.  Nicely layed out with many artifacts....we had our own guide but there was a local gentleman who was very eager to show and tell us about this place...he was very proud.  The gounds are beautiful and the huge trees provided welcome shade.

Martin Wickramasinghe museum is a large scaled museum and it has a lot of things. It's maintained by the children of Martin Wickramasinghe. There are chariots, carts, elephant carriages etc. also there are boats, canoes etc. these are not models but the real actually used ones. It features the house in which Martin Wickramasinghe was born and the history of it is awesome. The toilets need to be properly maintained.

One of the most important writers that Sri Lanka has ever produced lived here in this very house. His writing was of highest order and depicted the reality of Sri Lankan folk life and its contrast to upcoming Sri Lankan elite capitalist class. His knowledge of society and common wisdom is unmatched. This place showcases the real Martin Wickramasinghe. The land surrounding the house was much bigger in 1980's. Now the Koggala trade zone has taken over some part of it.

This museum in Koggola near Unawatuna is a fascinating collection of Sri Lankan culture: great artifacts housed in Wickramasinghe's property.  There is a particularly good collection of  masks, some of which show old colonials, and jewelry.   The exhibits are poorly dated with little information, but a guide approached us and filled us in on the details.  There was a good model of an ancient Sri Lankan tank, used for irrigation; it did explain why some national parks are based round a 'tank'.  It was the only time we saw a snake: its tail was hanging from the coconut palm roof of a model house!  Lovely grounds - peaceful despite the large number of school visits.

This museum is built around Martin Wickramasinghe's house - you can visit his house and pause to reflect on where this far-sighted Sri Lankan legend and his family lived. The museum itself is informative with a variety of displays.  You can learn about the engineering feat that established the 'tanks' that serviced irrigation in the dry central zone of Sri Lanka 4 centuries BC as well as enjoying a vivid display of masks ranging from the old and traditional to the modern and current.  Archeological explorations are revealing the nature of Sri Lankan culture from prehistoric times. We were helped to understand aspects of Buddhism and Sinhalese culture by a knowledgeable gentleman - the exhibits are not comprehensively labelled in English (but then the British Museum doesn't label all its displays in Sinhala does it?).  He didn't expect payment either! The grounds are lovely too, beautifully tended with many of the trees labelled with their scientific names.  A thoroughly fulfilling visit which I would recommend without hesitation!

I had heard about the museum built around Martin Wickramasinghe's house before and finally got to have a look this week. The museum is just off the road between Galle and Matara, and while there is a sign pointing you in the direction to it (across from the Fortress hotel), you may make the mistake of taking a left turn instead of going straight to the parking lot, as I did. The grounds which surround the museum are nice and peaceful. As seems to be the case at a lot of Sri Lankan attractions, the species of tree are all labeled, and you may catch sight of a monitor lizard or two. I didn't actually stop by the house itself, as it was a short stop, but the museum is well worth checking out. It ends up taking you through 3 or 4 rooms that are filled with collections of tools, art, jewelery and other artefacts, as well as transportation such as carts and boats. I almost feel it's better than the national museum in Colombo, in a way.

I took a bus from the Southeast to Galle aware of this museum. I had planned of going there but transportation seemed hard due to Kogalla being on the way to Galle. When I was on the bus I decided to just get off at the town and a guy took me on his scooter there. It was very pleasant! The guy whose office was in the canteen area was really nice! He was a former teacher and found a job at the museum. He helped me take care of my heavy rucksack when the guys at the entrance refused to take it in as I look around. His in-depth knowledge was very helpful and gave more insights about Sri Lankan folk history.

This museum was just a short walk from my hotel and had been well reviewed in my guidebook, and I wasn't disappointed.  The museum is set in a large park with beautiful trees, each labelled with its name.  The main thing to see is the Folk Museum, which has 3 rooms all about Sri Lankan history and culture.  It's a bit dingy and old-fashioned in its layout, but the exhibits were really interesting, particularly the dance masks and life-size traditional puppets.  I was also interested to find out about the ancient iron and steel industry, with excellent diagrams and model, thanks to research by Exeter University.  There was also a museum of costumes which was well worth seeing.  In a large covered area outside was a display of carts, coaches and carriages from the past, though most of these were in a bad state of repair and could do with some restoration.  Finally I went to the small traditional bungalow which had been the home of Martin Wickramainghe, who was one of the foremost Sri Lankan writers of the 20th century.  The simple house was very evocative of times past, and the exhibition room at the back, full of old documents and photographs, really told the story of the author's life and personality.  I enjoyed my visit very much, and it's a great place to go if the weather's bad!

This is a great place for an insight into Sri Lankan life, as the museum contains wonderful displays showing all aspects of life. There were some school visits while I was there, and it was nice to see the place being well used and appreciated.  I wish the management had spent a little bit of the admission fee on cooling the air.  There were fans, but they weren't switched on, so everyone was very hot and sweaty.
Large collection reflecting local costumes, masks, local trades; enthusiastic staff keen to provide explanations and point out things you might have missed.  What's not to like?

I visited this museum recently; and spent over two hours looking at the wide array of art,literature and cultural exhibits, and of course learning a lot of important facts about the life of Sri Lanka's father of Sinhala literature - Mr. Martin Wickramasinghe. I couldn't stop admiring his life and literature and at the end of the tour - I was yearning to buy his books, And then there is a well stocked shop of his books in Sinhala and English. I ended up buying five books-they were reasonably priced. Wish I bought more. Any way I plan to go there again very soon. I think this museum is a must visit by both locals and foreigners. For the foreign travellers those who want to admire local cultures - this is  an ideal place. But sadly, during my stay there, I didn't see a single foreigner - although there are several big and famous tourist hotels are located in the surroundings. The entrance to the museam is just opposite the Fortress Hotel. And then there are many other hotels in that coastal strech. Sadly, it appears that none of those hotels has taken the initiative to inform their visitors about this hidden gem. However, I must say - the locals visit the place in big numbers.

We expected this museum to be a small scale establishment with a handful of exhibits. WE WERE WRONG! This is undoubtedly one of the best museums in the country stretching to a vast area and a multitude of exhibits showing the cultural heritage and the past of the award winning Sri Lankan author.
We were travelling from Galle to Mirissa and popped into the museum for an hour along the way.  There's enought to keep you amused for an hour.

I visited this place a part of a research for one of my friends on masks of Sri Lanka & its evolution. This gave me the opportunity to explore the site which is an almost complete complex consisting of the authentic Sri Lankan village lifestyle. They have household equipment, transport vehicles, house models, etc Also one of the best collection of Sri Lankan masks can be seen here. Mr. Martin Wickramasinghe is a well known author in Sri Lanka who's house can also be seen at this location. Mr. Wickramasinghe started this museum in the hopes of showing the world what the ancient Sri Lankan village lifestyle was all about. Now the Martin Wicramasinghe foundation maintains it. Take the road right in front of "The Fortress" hotel which ends at the museum.
Opened up a new world of Sri Lankan culture for us. Martin W.'s delightful house like a little cottage was a highlight.

Situated in Koggala in a huge piece of land where the author Martin Wickremasinghe's original house is situated. The house displays the room and the bed he was born and the rest of the house where he used to live. This has an exhibition and a sale of his book collection where  I too was able to buy few books for my personal use. Needs a lot of maintenance around the place and worth a visit if you are passing by though I made a special visit to the place.
It has been change to museum. IN the past time it was ancestral home of Hon;martin wickramasingha's. You must have to go there. Good experience about fisherman's culture in past time also

Martin Wickramasinghe's writing evoked a village life when he was growning up, which was already changing, if not dying out, when his novels were published. Visiting the museum is akin to revisiting that time. It's easy to imagine barefoot boys running around Koggala Lake, when strolling around this complex.
We had a wonderful visit here.  It's a small museum - maybe an hour's visit - but you get a really interesting insight into Sinhalese life. Definitely worth the effort going to see it.

Talk to the guide, he is full of real information about every aspect of the Museum. it covers every aspect of real peoples lives. I have been there three times and still see a new aspect on every visit.Any one who visits me is dragged there and come out enchanted. History buffs, social historians, just those who want to know how life has been lived in Sri Lanka for centuries will enjoy this experience.

Though I was expecting a small house, which veteran Martin Wickramasinghe lived with some photos, there was lot more. Te folk museum is amazing compiling various folks, pottery, painting, farming etc etc. Exhibits were spanned over all 9 kingdoms and most of them are inspiring. The house was a delight to watch, felt being part of a life of Mr. Wickramasinghe after watching.

This is where the writer lived and worked.  It has been kept in its original state and is pretty interesting to see.  It may appeal more to locals than foreigners as they would be more familiar with his writing.

If the hedonistic delights of the turquoise beaches of southern Sri Lanka can get a bit overwhleming, there is a peaceful getaway in the town of Koggala just off the A2 (Galle Road),beyond Galle and directly opposite the spa hotel intimidatingly called The Fortress. Titled the Martin Wickramasinghe Museum of Folk Culture,the attraction, to visit which there is a small admission fee, is spread over several acres around his birthplace and has been visualised as a memorial to this doyen of Sri Lankan writers and a man of letters. Such a initiative was close to his heart and therefore the Trust in his name has built a museum depicting folk arts and crafts and folk technology,and re-creates the work of craftsmen and their role in rural society. Following entry,one traverses a path through several interesting botanical specimens of trees, Walking Pine tree,Golden Shower pudding pipe tree,Beauty Leaf Alexandrian laurel and other unique varieties before reaching the small house where Martin Wickramasinghe was born.It was designed as a home typical of the headman,the tacher,and the native physician, the rural village gentry of the early 19th century.A samadhi (grave)where his ashes were interred in 1976  and later his wife's in 2001 are nearby. The samadhi and the house of his birth are symbols that span over seven decades of continuous intellectual exploration and creative writing. The high-roofed,spacious halls of the Folk Museum house a vast array of artifacts of Sri Lankan folk culture and life. Traditional vehicles used for travel and transport such as carriages and canoes are displayed in separate sheds. One can easily spend 2-3 hours in this memorial absorbing the many facets of Sri Lankan culture before being rejuvenated to experience the modern way of life in this beautiful country.
away from the hustle and bustle of the town it brings back memories of yesteryear. The old house and the huge garden makes one feel how peaceful life would have been in the old days gone by.

Presented tastefully, the exhibits are preserved quite well for the time being. Some areas are dusty and covered with cobwebs. We spent more than 3hours and and learnt more things by the minute till we left. The garden is beautiful and loved the old artifacts. Having read quite a few of Wickramasinge's books, it was like putting a face to the stories of the great writer.
Medium sized exhibit of Sri Lankan history, well done. Masks and story on iron smelting (really) were the highlights.

This was originally started as the Martin Wickramasinghe Memorial museum in His ancestral home. Now it covers a lot of aspects of Sri Lankan heritage with sprawling complex of buildings displays some working replicas of the past. The Original Museum is there displaying about the life of the great Sinhala Author Martin Wickramasinghe. In Addition you can see the old Fishing Boats, Bullock carts, Horse drawn carts and few elephant carts as well which covers most of the ancient modes of transport. Then they have huge collection of industrial and domestic equipment used in the past. One should see exhibit is the ancient steel manufacturing system displayed there.  Also some weapons of war too can be seen. They have also built and operate working replicas of village blacksmiths workshop, a weaving mill, Coconut oil refinery, and few other old village industries. They also have a sort of picnic grounds so if you come up with packed lunch or picnic basket you can enjoy it there as well.

Martin Wickramasinghe folk museum is not only worth due to the house and to see his great work, but also it is very important to see the various aspects of Sinhala culture in the folk museum. The only house in Koggala which escaped demolition to build the airport.

This is the childhood home of Martin Wickramasinghe a Sri Lankan author with whom I was admittedly unfamiliar.  Admission is very minimal.  The property contains a good folk museum with historical items related to various periods of Sri Lankan history.  The grounds are large and peaceful.  Visitors can walk through the author's small house.  While there, we were approached by a gentleman who identified himself as the author's son, Ranga.  He autographed copies of his father's books, which he had translated into English, and discussed a current political situation.  I have enjoyed reading the books he signed.  Although the chance meeting made the visit more memorable, this folk museum provides an good opportunity to experience Sri Lankan history and culture in a peaceful setting.

The Martin Wickramasinghe Folk Museum has very nice and interesting artifacts showing Sri Lanka's folk culture.  I had no idea who Martin Wickramashinghe was before going there but while strolling the premises we were approached by this very nice older gentleman.  It turned out that he was actually the son of Martin Wickramasinghe himself (Ranga Wickramashinghe)!  He engaged us in a very interesting conversation and gave us hand-signed copies of two of his father’s books that he translated from Sinhalese to English.  He also called us over to enjoy fresh coconut harvested from one of the trees on the estate.  This is really something we did not expect from visiting this place!  It was a very lucky coincidence but the place is well worth seeing ... even without this “interesting encounter” …

This is the birthplace of the famous author Martin Wickramasinghe. It has a folk arts centre, with museum and his birth home. Rich in detail, very well maintained and an oasis in midst of galle. A must to visit

Located on the land side of the Galle Matara Road at Koggala. Marin Wickramasinghe is the Sinhalese author modern times. He has written over 80 books, several of which have been translated into foreign languages. The center has last collection of artifacts of Sinhalese culture is displayed at this museum. There is a bookshop you can buy his books. Also they provide the quick printing services for the Souvenirs printing..
Interesting and eye opening. The Masks and puppets are great. Definitely worth a visit.
Very Interesting Museum, 200rup in, take some an hour or two away from the beach and visit this place.  Great for kids too
